Why Upgrade Your Consumer Unit?

An old fuse box or outdated consumer unit may not provide adequate protection for modern electrical demands. Upgrading to a modern consumer unit with RCBOs (Residual Current Breaker with Overcurrent protection) significantly improves electrical safety.

Signs You Need an Upgrade

  • • Old-style fuse box with wire fuses
  • • No RCD protection
  • • Frequent tripping or electrical faults
  • • Consumer unit over 15+ years old
  • • Insurance requirements

Modern Consumer Unit Features

RCBOs (Recommended)

Individual circuit protection combining MCB and RCD functionality. If one circuit develops a fault, only that circuit trips - not the whole house.

Surge Protection Device (SPD)

Protects your expensive appliances and electronics from power surges caused by lightning or grid switching.

Clear Circuit Labeling

Professional labeling so you know exactly which circuit controls what in your home.

Full Certification

Installation certificate and Building Control notification included.

Frequently Asked Questions

How long does an upgrade take?

Most consumer unit upgrades are completed in 4-6 hours, often done in a single day with power restored the same day.

Will I be without power?

Yes, power will be off during installation. We work efficiently to minimize disruption, typically 4-6 hours total.

Do I need Building Control approval?

We handle all Building Control notifications as part of our service - no extra paperwork for you.

What's the difference between MCBs and RCBOs?

RCBOs provide individual earth leakage protection per circuit, whereas MCBs rely on a shared RCD. RCBOs offer better fault isolation.

Is surge protection necessary?

While not legally required, SPDs protect expensive appliances and electronics from power surges. Increasingly recommended by electricians.

How often should consumer units be replaced?

Modern consumer units typically last 20+ years, but units over 15 years old may benefit from upgrading to current safety standards.
